title: Abstract 444: BRM/SMARCA2 is a critical synthetic lethal target in BRG1-deficient cancers
abstract: The mammalian SWI/SNF complexes (mSWI/SNF) regulate chromatin structure through ATP-dependent nucleosome remodeling and thereby control key cellular processes. Recent cancer genome studies have revealed a significant frequency of mutations in several components of the mSWI/SNF complexes including the catalytic subunit BRG1. Emerging evidence is supportive of tumor suppressor roles for mSWI/SNF subunits, yet the inactivating nature of these mutations presents a challenge for devising targeted therapeutic strategies against cancers harboring such mutations. In this study, we interrogated epigenetic cancer dependencies by screening a deep-coverage design (DeCoDe) shRNA library targeting the epigenome across a broad range of 50+ cancer cell lines. Strikingly, this unbiased screen revealed that silencing of the SWI/SNF ATPase subunit BRM/SMARCA2, selectively inhibits the proliferation of BRG1-deficient cancer cells. BRM knockdown selectively induced cell cycle arrest in BRG1-mutant cancer cells and significantly impaired the growth of BRG1-mutant lung tumor xenografts. BRM is the paralog of BRG1, suggesting a model in which mSWI/SNF mutations lead to a hypomorphic complex that promotes tumorigenesis but cannot tolerate complete inactivation. Thus, targeting mSWI/SNF subunits that exhibit redundant activities to the residual mutated complexes may present a general strategy for SWI/SNF mutated cancers. Citation Format: Mariela Jaskelioff, Gregory Hoffman, Rami Rahal, Kay Xiang, Kristy Haas, Veronica Saenz-Vash, Huili Zhai, Nicholas Keen, Frank Stegmeier, Zainab Jagani. BRM/SMARCA2 is a critical synthetic lethal target in BRG1-deficient cancers. [abstract]. In: Proceedings of the 105th Annual Meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research; 2014 Apr 5-9; San Diego, CA. Philadelphia (PA): AACR; Cancer Res 2014;74(19 Suppl):Abstract nr 444. doi:10.1158/1538-7445.AM2014-444

motivations: Mutations in the mammalian SWI/SNF complexes, including the catalytic subunit BRG1, are frequently found in cancers and present a challenge for targeted therapeutic strategies.
There is a need to identify synthetic lethal targets in BRG1-deficient cancers to devise effective treatments.
objectives: Identify epigenetic cancer dependencies that can be targeted in BRG1-deficient cancers.
Investigate the role of BRM/SMARCA2 as a potential synthetic lethal target in BRG1-deficient cancers.
methods: Screen a deep-coverage design shRNA library targeting the epigenome across a range of cancer cell lines.
Use cell cycle arrest and tumor xenograft growth assays to validate the effects of BRM knockdown in BRG1-mutant cancer cells.
results: BRM/SMARCA2 is a critical synthetic lethal target in BRG1-deficient cancers.
Targeting BRM/SMARCA2 can selectively inhibit the proliferation of BRG1-deficient cancer cells and impair tumor growth.
llama_json.research_subject: Identification of synthetic lethal targets in BRG1-deficient cancers

motivations: Mutations in the mSWI/SNF complexes, including the catalytic subunit BRG1, are common in cancers, but the inactivating nature of these mutations presents a challenge for targeted therapeutic strategies.
There is a need to understand the dependencies of cancers on the epigenome to identify potential therapeutic targets.
objectives: Screen a deep-coverage design (DeCoDe) shRNA library targeting the epigenome across a broad range of cancer cell lines to identify potential therapeutic targets.
Investigate the effect of silencing the SWI/SNF ATPase subunit BRM/SMARCA2 on the proliferation of BRG1-deficient cancer cells.
methods: Conduct an unbiased screen using a DeCoDe shRNA library targeting the epigenome across a range of cancer cell lines.
Assess the impact of BRM knockdown on cell cycle arrest and growth of BRG1-mutant lung tumor xenografts.
results: Silencing of the SWI/SNF ATPase subunit BRM/SMARCA2 selectively inhibits the proliferation of BRG1-deficient cancer cells.
BRM knockdown selectively induced cell cycle arrest in BRG1-mutant cancer cells and significantly impaired the growth of BRG1-mutant lung tumor xenografts.
openai_json.research_subject: Identifying synthetic lethal targets in BRG1-deficient cancers

motivations: Mutations in mSWI/SNF complexes, particularly in the catalytic subunit BRG1, are frequently found in cancers, but their inactivating nature makes it challenging to develop targeted therapeutic strategies.
There is a need to identify vulnerabilities in cancers harboring mSWI/SNF mutations that can be exploited for therapeutic intervention.
objectives: Identify epigenetic dependencies in cancer cells through systematic screening of epigenome-targeting factors.
Investigate whether BRM/SMARCA2 represents a synthetic lethal target in BRG1-deficient cancers.
methods: Screen a deep-coverage design (DeCoDe) shRNA library targeting the epigenome across 50+ cancer cell lines.
Perform functional validation of BRM knockdown effects on cell proliferation, cell cycle, and tumor growth in BRG1-mutant models.
results: BRM/SMARCA2 silencing selectively inhibits proliferation and induces cell cycle arrest in BRG1-deficient cancer cells.
BRM knockdown significantly impairs the growth of BRG1-mutant lung tumor xenografts, demonstrating therapeutic potential.
The findings suggest a synthetic lethal relationship between BRM and BRG1 that can be exploited for cancer therapy.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Synthetic lethality of BRM/SMARCA2 in BRG1-deficient cancers
